After Halden died, everything started slipping. Then the Directorate weaponized truth—those public confessions were strategic, not honest.
But the whistleblower leaks—that was different. They published full audit logs showing disappearances and how BCI compliance was quietly forced. I recognized some names.
Free zone leaders pulled the city together for real investigations. For once, families could demand answers.
We even saw leads on Halden’s old protocols—some used them to open resource stores. Not everyone believes it, but I think he left it as a backup for citizen control.
I grew up thinking the system was rational. I see now how much happened that never should have. My brother’s case is probably in those logs.
Inside the labs, techs exchange evidence quietly. Hard to trust anyone, but the Innovator ideas—open protocols, fair audits—are finally getting traction in the free zones.
The Council is fractured. Directorate’s losing its grip. The only thing holding people together is this new idea of public accountability.
Work is hard, but I’d rather be part of this shift than stuck following the old system.
Feels lighter, even if everything is uncertain.
